div.p: 1. IV. Saturday.

I finished this morning the first weeding of my Nursery for the Season: and I endeavoured to shelter some of my fresh seedlings from the Sun— I planted under the young Pear tree at the West end of the Garden, and thence to the fence 40. wintered shell bark walnuts in a row and some elm seeds over them. And I discovered in that patch two Oaks just out of the ground— Had afternoon visits from Mr Bailey and Mr Goddard of Washington— The Ladies took tea, and Charles and I went in the Evening to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, where we found Mr and Mrs Angier— Mr Edward Miller was also there. He has come out with his family from Boston for the Summer. Mrs Adams desired me to speak to Mr Angier about her Son John Quincy— I received yesterday a Letter from Mrs Maria Brooks, concerning her Poem of Zophiel, and enclosing a Letter of Robert Southey to her— And this day I had a Letter from Robert Newman of Romney, Virginia concerning his Views of the Solar System— I wrote part of a Letter to Edward Livingston, who is no longer Secretary of State. John Randolph of Roanoke died at Philadelphia, on Friday of last week the 24th. of May.
2. IV.15. Sunday

Mr Whitney preached from Luke 23.46. “And when Jesus had cried with a loud voice, he said, Father, into thy hands I commend my Spirit; and having said thus, he gave up the Ghost.”— He administered the Communion, and his afternoon text was from John 14.23. “Jesus answered and said unto him, If a man love me, he will keep my words”—upon which he delivered a very earnest exhortation to his Christian hearers, to join in communion with the Church— This would have been a very proper subject for the morning’s discourse— Instead of which he introduced into that a very strange argument in mitigation of the crimes of Judas Iscariot, which he represented as having been exaggerated— Mr Whitney did not intend to justify Judas Iscariot, but he does not believe in eternal punishment— His object was to urge that punishment less than everlasting torment may atone even for his crimes— But to extenuate the crime, is not the most discreet or rational means of obtaining remission of the punishment.— I read the fourth Sermon of the third volume of Saurin, upon the sublimest devotion— An ingenious and learned discourse upon enthusiastic Religion—one of the remarkable vagaries of the human mind— Saurin disapproves of mysticism, and fanaticism; but recommends religious fervour scarcely falling short of them. Mrs Angier and Elizabeth C. Adams were here at tea— Mr Angier returned to Medford this Morning. Towards Evening I took a turn in my Garden and Nursery— Found a number of the Elm seeds which I had planted on the 16th. of May, coming up. This experiment is now thus far complete— The seeds should be gathered as they fall from the trees, from the 15th. of May to the 1st. of June— Sown immediately in loose ground and barely covered with Earth— The seed leaves that come up are scarcely perceptible— Not larger than those of chickweed— How they will stand the heat of the Sun is next to be seen. Price Greenleaf’s grafts of the present year, and his buds of August 1831 are vegetating with great promise. I found also in one of my boxes, a seed of the honey locust, which has been two years in the ground coming up— And in the garden, one new Oak.— The Apple seedlings of the present year, will all perish unless sheltered from the Sun.
3. IV. Monday.

Interrupted in my morning labour in the garden by my namesake, who came for a Letter from his brother, the Lieutenant to his Sister Elizabeth, which he brought with him, and was under a cover addressed to me— Mr Peake is a travelling agent to procure subscriptions for Newspapers and printed Books— He brought me the first and second numbers of the National Gallery of Portraits of which I had already received the first number— I took the second. Mr Carey is an Old Revolutionary Soldier
from North-Bridgewater, who came to see me for curiosity— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— I was great part of the afternoon as well as of the morning in the Nursery. Having ascertained that the Elm seeds vegetate freely and in less than three weeks from the planting, I was desirous of making the experiment more extensively, and gathered a few more of the Seeds in the Road;—though it may be probably now too late— I killed a large Snake who had found his way into the midst of the garden. I find upon the leaves of my trees swarms of aphides turning to small flies; and other swarms of Ants, preying upon them— I wrote to Charles Folsom, corresponding Secretary of the Φ.B.K. Society declining to deliver their next Anniversary Oration, which I had conditionally engaged to do. My labours of the garden have brought me into a total Eclipse.
4. IV:10. Tuesday.

Henry Hardwick came this morning while I was at work in the Garden, about the strip of Saltmarsh land which he wishes to purchase on the Mount Wollaston farm—which I promised to take into further consideration— Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf paid us an Evening visit— I am still occupied in weeding my Nursery, a work constantly to be renewed. My seedling Oaks from the last Autumn’s plantation of Acorns, are no longer coming up, and the number that have appeared scarcely amounts to the thirty— No appearance yet of walnuts— My seedling Elms are already perishing under the radiance of the Sun— It is the fable of Jupiter and Semele— I finished reading the Septuagint book of Genesis, and began that of Exodus—in C. Thomson’s Translation— I read also the notes of Hewlett, and a few of those of Scott—which are tedious— The enquiry occurred to me this morning, what and how many are the different modes of Revelation—or of supernatural communication from God to man are recognized in the Bible.
5. IV. Wednesday.

I received a Letter from Mrs Maria Brooks, I believe an English woman; a Stranger to me. She informs me that she has written a poem, called Zophiel, in six Cantos, which has the approbation of Robert Southey and Washington Irving— It is now in the Press in England, under the direction of Mr Southey— Mrs Brooks expects it in a few days, and wishes me to accept a copy of it, when it comes— She wishes also a recommendation of it by me, and proposes to publish an edition of it in every one of the large cities of the United States—the profits of the Sales to be applied to the benefit of the Polish Patriots— Mrs Brooks sent me with her Letter—one to herself from Robert Southey, written at Keswick in March last, about the publication of the Poem— He promises that it shall last— Also a slip from Evening Gazette at Boston containing a very favourable Review of Dermot MacMorrogh, signed M, and no doubt written by herself—a French Translation in Manuscript of the Harper’s Song in Dermot, and the arguments of the six Cantos of Zophiel— I answered this Letter, and it was altogether a painful task— The Labour of the day though very short— I was morning and afternoon in my garden, and gathered a parcel of Elm Seeds under the Trees. Having ascertained that they come up freely, I would now collect a large parcel to plant them, though I believe it now too late— I found on the largest of the Cherry trees that I have raised in the garden Nursery, Myriads, perhaps hundreds of thousands of a small black louse or fly, and the same leaves covered with black Ants— Here and there a seedling Oak is coming up, of the many hundreds which I planted last Autumn— Almost all my seedling Apples of the present year, are scorched to death by the Sun— The Cherries follow to like destruction—it is doubtful whether one of either kind will be left— The wild cherry bears it much better.— In spending four or five hours a day in the nursery, I do not sufficiently realize it as a waste of time.
6. IV. Thursday— Boston— Quincy

I went to Boston this morning with Charles— Paid visits to Alexander H. Everett, Dr G. Parkman, Isaac P. Davis, Mr Abbott Lawrence, Judge Joseph Hall, and Mr Thomas L Winthrop, and Mrs Dexter. Everett and Hall only were at home— Under the Elm Trees on the Common, there was a great profusion of the fallen seed, of which I gathered a small quantity— Just one fortnight too late— At noon I attended a Meeting of the Overseers of Harvard University, at the Council Chamber in the State House— The Corporation had elected Simon Greenleaf of Portland, Maine, Professor of Law, in the place of Mr Ashmun lately deceased, and this Meeting of the Overseers was called, to see if they would confirm the appointment— There is a rule adopted in April 1832. that no appointment of a Professor shall be confirmed, except at a Meeting while the Legislature is in Session, nor then, but after an interval of not less than 7 days, after the name has been presented—unless the meeting by a majority of at least three fourths of the members present, determine to proceed immediately to vote upon the nomination— A debate arose upon the question whether this rule should be rescinded or suspended in which A. H. Everett—James T. Austin, H. Hubbard, Chief Justice Shaw, Edward Everett and myself took part, as did the President Quincy, Mr Pierce of Brookline, Mr Adan, Doctor Porter, Dr Codman and Doctor Lowell. It was finally concluded not to rescind or suspend the rule, and the nomination of Mr Greenleaf was not confirmed— While I was at the Meeting Dr Parkman came and urged me so earnestly to dine with him that I consented— He had also engaged Charles— Old Mrs Parkman the mother, and a Mr and Mrs Jackson of Philadelphia were of the party— And Mr and Mrs Daniel Parkman, and Judge Peter Thacher and his wife— We returned to Quincy towards Evening— While I was absent Dr Zacchaeus Bartlett of Plymouth had called to see me, and was much disappointed at not meeting me at home. I visited my garden before Night.
7. IV:15. Friday.

The first seedling Apple-tree that I had observed on my return here, just out of the ground was on the 22d. of April. It had grown slowly but constantly since, and had put out five or six leaves— Last evening after my return from Boston I saw it, perfectly sound— This morning I found it broken off, leaving one lobe of the seed leaves, and one leaf over it— This may have been the work of a bug, or perhaps of a Caterpillar— It would not be imaginable, to any person free from hobby-horses, or fanciful attachments, how much mortification such an incident occasions— St Evremond, after removing into the Country, returned to a City life, because he found himself in despair for the loss of a pigeon— His conclusion was that rural life induced exorbitant attachments to insignificant objects— My experience is conformable to this— My natural propensity was to raise trees—fruit and forest, from the seed— I had it in early youth, but the course of my life deprived me of the means of pursuing the bent of my inclination. One Shellbark walnut tree in my garden, the nut of which I planted 8. October 1804. and one Mazzard Cherry tree in the grounds North of the The Stone of which I planted about the same time, are the only remains of my experiments of so ancient a date— Had my life been spent in the Country, and my experiments commenced, while I was at College—I should now have a large fruit garden; flourishing Orchards of native fruit, and very valuable Forests— Instead of which, I have a Nursery of about half an Acre of ground; half full of seedlings from five years, to five days old; bearing for the first time perhaps twenty peaches, and a few blossoms of
Apricots and Cherries, and hundreds of seedlings of the present year, perishing from day to day, before my eyes— I worked three hours of this Morning, and planted a long row in the garden of wintered walnuts, cherries [symbols] and Elm seeds— Of these planted between the 15th. and 25th. of last month I have several up in three different places— I did not return to the Garden after dinner, but slept away the time— Read part of the second Book of Cicero’s Offices, translated by G. A. Otis— I received a Letter from Lewis Cass Secretary of War, enclosing Certificates of Pensions for Revolutionary Services, to Samuel Belcher for 100 dollars a year, and to Solomon Thayer for 116 dollars 66 cents a year.
8. IV. Saturday.

Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine; and John Kirk went, and brought out our Trunks last arrived from Washington— I was for three hours after breakfast in my garden Nursery, and finished the second weeding of the central Alley— Finished also planting the Row of wintered walnuts. steeped cherries, and Tupelo berries, and Elm Seeds. The first four or five ripe Strawberries were found in the Garden. Mrs Edward Miller, and Elizabeth C. Adams were here before dinner; and Mrs Baxter and Mrs Lee, in the afternoon I rode with the Ladies, and called at Mr Solomon Thayers, and gave him his certificate for a pension, for which he thanked me, but thought it was for not more than half what he was entitled to— He told me a long Story of his labours and services, and said he could prove that his wages were 20 dollars a Month— I told him if he would collect the Evidence of this and bring it to me, I would apply to the Secretary of War for an increase of his Pension; which I had obtained in a similar case for another person, whose Certificate came yesterday with his— He shewed me his field of grain, two Acres thickly covered, and half grown.— The same grain which perished in the hands of both my Tenants Carr and Alpheus Spear— I am reading the trial of Ephraim K. Avery, a Methodist Preacher, for the murder of Sarah M. Cornell—a Factory Girl— Trial at Newport, R.I. he was acquitted—as by fire— Read also 3. Chapters of the Offices.
9. IV:10. Sunday.

Heard Mr Mellish Motte, now a settled Minister in Boston— In the Morning from Ephesians 6.24. “Grace be with all them that love our Lord Jesus Christ in Sincerity”—and afternoon from 1. John. 2.25 “And this is the promise that he hath promised us, even eternal life.” His delivery is an alternation of languid monotony, and strong emphasis, which all together commands attention— He made an apology for Judas Iscariot; almost in the same terms, used by Mr Whitney, last Sunday; and with the same current of ideas— Mr Motte dined with us.— I read the 5th. Sermon of the 3d volume of Saurin, on the Life of Courtiers; from 2. Samuel 19.32–39. The Story of Barzillai the Gileadite, and David— The most impressive and practical discourse of this Author that I have yet read— The Lesson that he draws from the story of his text was that a kingly Court is a place suitable for a young, but not for an Old Man— This Sermon is in the manner of several of those of Sterne; a kind of parable of which the moral is mingled up with the narrative. The preacher speaks of Courts and Courtiers, with less of indignation, but not with less of severity than Massillon— I have special motives for reflecting upon this Sermon, which contains just remarks upon the duty of old men to retire from public action and inspection; applicable not only to Courts of Kings, but to all active participation in public affairs— Charles’s child is quite unwell— Dry and cold weather— We had a fire in our dining room.
10. IV:10. Monday.

Charles went and dined at Boston— Mr Eliphaz Thayer of Braintree came with Deacon Spear— He is a claimant for a Revolutionary Pension, and his papers have been so long at the War Department that he has become impatient, and hearing that I had obtained a Certificate for Solomon Thayer, he came to ask my assistance to obtain his— Mr Loud and Mr Hayward, both of Braintree came with a similar request— They said their papers had been at the Department ever since last August— I wrote to the Secretary of War in behalf of them all— I received from the acting Secretary of War, John Robb a Letter enclosing the Petition and Voucher of Constant Fobes Oakman—for further Evidence— I wrote also a short answer to Mr John Angier’s Letter, concerning my nephew John Quincy Adams— Mr Curtis was here, and we had a consultation respecting the disposal of some of the real Estate of Mr W. N. Boylston— He had a plan for building two houses on land in Milk Street, Boston— The Estate in Corn Court, Mr Curtis inclines to sell—but it has been long in the family, and there is a clause in the will, directing that the hereditary property should be the last sold.— I am to take some opportunity to look at it— I returned to Mr Curtis, Mr P. Vaughan’s Letter of 6. Novr last, and Mr Lowell, will make a draft of a Release and Indemnity for us to execute, upon which Petty Vaughan promises to remit some of the money due to us— Mr Curtis gave me the Account of Mrs Boylston, for maintenance of the two boys my wards— After dinner, I found it impracticable to write— Walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and gave her a Letter from her Son the Lieutenant, at Pittsburgh.— After a long succession of dry weather, this afternoon and Evening there were two or three light Showers— Weeding my Nursery; and planted 8 red Strawberries, just ripe, for experiment.
11. IV. Tuesday.

Weather variable— Light showers morning and Evening; and so cold that we had fires in the dining room and bed-chambers—but not in my writing-chamber— I spent almost the whole morning in my Nursery, and the afternoon in the Garden. In weeding with the hoe, I work to produce a streaming perspiration, and think its effect very favourable to my health. The labour is its own, and almost its only reward. I am preparing the patch at the bottom of my nursery, already covered with young Elms and English Oaks, to plant seeds in the rows between them for the benefit of the shade when they come up— At least three fourths of all my Apple-seedlings of this year have perished for want of shade— Many cherries have had the same fate— This afternoon, I deposited an Earthen Pot at the west end of my garden, with four white ripe Strawberries, and I propose to multiply the experiment of raising Strawberries from the Seed— In the same pot I also planted 6 Steeped Cherries— From the young Apricot tree there, I took out a large white worm. A few of the Elms which first came up, are putting out their second set of leaves, but are yet no bigger than a pin’s head. Among the vegetations of this year, is here and there a grape and a currant— The damp weather gave me a rhumatic head-ache, which disqualified me much for reading or writing.
12. IV:45 Wednesday.

Mr Joscelyn and Mr Bryant are a Committee of the Bunker Hill Monument Association, to collect contributions for completing the monument upon Bunker Hill; a project which has just been revived with great fervour and for which there have been public Meetings and eloquent Speeches, and spunging Committees to collect Subscriptions in all the towns round Boston— I declined giving any further contribution, observing that I had given 100 dollars
at the first undertaking of the work, and thought that was my full proportion; and I added that I was not altogether satisfied with the manner in which the first contributions had been expended— Mr Joscelyn said he believed the charges against the Directors, of mismangement of the funds were ill founded, a satifactory explanation and statement of their proceedings having been given by them— I said it might be so—but I had not seen it— Mr Bryant thanked me for the assistance I had given at the Session of Congress before last, in obtaining an act of Congress for the payment of a claim which he and his associates had against the Government, and which was refused upon a senseless opinion given by the Attorney General Roger B. Taney— This afternoon a man alighted at my house from the Stage, and directed the Stageman to call for him here, next Monday Morning— He came in and announced himself as an old and very intimate acquaintance by the name of Hart— I recognized neither him nor his name— He said his intimacy with me had been at Mr Macqueen’s house at the Hague in 1795 and 1796 and 7. It was with my brother Thomas; whose intimacy at Macqueen’s I well remember, but in which I had no participation— I saw Macqueen several times; but never was at his house— Macqueen was an Englishman who kept a jewellers shop— Holland and Great-Britain were then at War, and as Minister from the United States I purposely abstained from frequenting an Englishman who was allowed to reside and keep his shop there; but was regarded with some Suspicion— Macqueen had a handsome and lively wife, and my brother was less scrupulous of acquaintance than I was. Mr Hart upon finding that he had now mistaken me for my brother, said that he recollected me— That my brother had introduced him to me, and he had then a project for coming to America and establishing a glass manufactory here—concerning which he had then consulted me— He said he had since then lived in various countries—particularly many years in France; before and after the downfall of Napoleon— That he had now been about five years in this Country, with which he was delighted— That he resided at New-York, but had recently come from Canada. That he now contemplated establishing a new manufactory, in Boston or its vicinity, of Files, Saws, and Pins; but it was a great undertaking and would require a large capital, and an associated company— I asked him if he knew any thing about the present condition of Macqueen or his family. He seemed unwilling to speak of them— He said there had been irregularities in the family— That Macqueen’s wife had left him and gone off with a Captain Stofford, Captain of an English small vessel of War, lost on the Coast of Holland, and whom he had often met with my brother at Macqueen’s— I remembered my brothers having repeatedly spoken to me of this Captain Stofford. I mentioned that Macqueen came to see me when I was at Ghent in 1814—and complained of having been severely persecuted and abused—and that he was then poor and miserable— I find in my Letter-book of that time a Letter to my brother of 17. September 1814 giving him an account of Macqueen’s visit to me, and of his complaints— His wife was then with him— I told Mr Hart that my brother died in March of last year; and I regretted his disappointment, on learning that his old friend was deceased, and I felt some mortification that Mr Harts account of his own adventures for the intervening forty years since his acquaintance with my brother, and his present speculative objects, with some apparent unwillingness to speak of his present Situation, prospects and connections in this Country, did not encourage me to offer him those hospitalities which he seemed confidently to have expected from my brother— After about half an hour’s conversation, he enquired the way to French’s Inn, to which he proceeded— Mr Daniel Greenleaf accompanied our Ladies home, returning from a visit to his wife— We heard this day of the terrible Catastrophe, the explosion of the Steamboat Lioness, on the Mississippi, by which Josiah S. Johnston the Senator, and Edward D. White member of the House from Louisiana, lost their Lives.
13. IV:15. Thursday

Luther Spear was here again about the purchase of forty-five Acres of my Land at the foot of Penn’s Hill— I told him I should ask 150 dollars an Acre for it— He said he could not give it so much as 50 dollars an Acre. I told him I had never expected we should agree about the price— Mr James H. Foster with his daughter Mary paid us a visit this afternoon, as did Mr Gourgas and Elizabeth C. Adams before dinner— In the Evening we all attended the annual Strawberry party at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s—Mrs Cranch with Mr John Greenleaf’s daughter Mrs Mary Dawes were there—Mrs Ritchie Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf—Mr and Mrs Edward Miller, Mr Smith and Drs. Woodward and Stetson. I was much of the day in the garden and Nursery. I filled a second Earthenware Pot with Earth, and planted in it six red Strawberries, and as many steeped Cherries— Whether the red and white Strawberry will each produce its kind is a question which I would settle by experiment— I found this day one Elm up, which I had sown on the 3d of this Month. The Elm seed therefore comes up in ten days— Charles discovered that one of the trees that I have been raising as a peach, and which bears this year for the first time is a Nectarine— The growth of all the seedlings that have come up this year is excessively slow, and nothing yet has a promise of life beyond the present Season.
14. IV.5. Friday.

Mr Belcher and his Son, came very punctually to the day, three weeks, from that of his former visit, as I had appointed with him. I gave him now the new certificate which I had received for him, from the Secretary of War, being for 100 dollars a year— On seeing it, he said it was more than he had asked for, his claim being for 8 dollars a month, or 96 dollars a year.— He appeared to be very highly delighted, and offered me some compensation for my trouble which I declined. He mentioned another man, at Braintree an applicant who had put in for a pension, and has long been waiting for an answer from the Secretary of War— He asked if he might send him to me, I said by all means— Mr Brown was here this afternoon, from Boston— He lives in my house at the corner of Tremont and Boylston Streets, and is connected with a Doctor Thomson, an Empyric Physician, who calls himself a Botanist— He came from him and mentioned that he wished to purchase the two houses, and enquired my price for them— I said 20000 dollars, which he thought a very high price— The value of land precisely at that spot, is raised and rising by the protraction of Tremont Street, and the widening of Boylston Street— He asked the quantity of Land there which I found upon examination was about 5000 feet— He said he would make his report to Mr Thomson, and left with me two Books, one being called a new Guide to health, or Botanic family Physicians; with an account of his life and medical discoveries; and the other a course of fifteen Lectures on Medical Botany, upon Thomson’s new Theory of Medical practice—delivered at Cincinnati Ohio, by Samuel Robinson— Deacon Spear was here towards Evening; and told me some extraordinary conduct of Luther Spear, in taking away from Deacon Savil a promisory Note of Luther’s, which Savil held in deposit. Deacon Spear enquired what had taken place between Luther and me, respecting his purchase of my Land at the foot of Penn’s Hill. I told him, and that there was no prospect of our agreeing upon the price— He thought Luther was crazy, and he is not far from it— I could work but little in my garden and Nursery this day—the warmth of the Sun suspended my weeding— I wrote Letters to my Son John at Washington, and to B. F. Hallett— Notes for 5000 4000 and 2000. at 90 days.
15. IV:45. Saturday.

The Summer is opening, and the Sun at once disables me for active labour in my garden— I strolled there however morning and afternoon observing how the Sun scorches to death my seedling plants— The Elm seeds planted within the last Month continue to come up in various places— There are upwards of 100 above ground— I planted [symbols] and Strawberries, white and red—and more Elm seeds— Also one Garden Railway Strawberry, in the Quart Tumbler. Judge Cranch was here with Mr Daniel Greenleaf— The judge left Washington, Wednesday Morning after breakfast and arrived here yesterday about five in the afternoon 500 miles in 60 hours— I had also a morning visit from the late Lieutt. Governor T. L. Winthrop— Towards Evening I walked with Charles to Mr John Greenleaf’s, and afterwards to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, where we met Judge and Mrs Cranch, Mrs John Greenleaf—Mrs and Joseph Angier, Mr Edward Miller’s daughter and Ann Beale— I walked home— Received a Letter with two Sermons from Mr Andrew Bigelow, who has recently been settled as Minister at Taunton; and a History of the United States from Mr Noah Webster—a School book for children.
16. IV. Sunday.

Heard Mr Joseph Angier, preach in the morning from Philippians 2.12.13. [“]Work out your own Salvation with fear and trembling:—For it is God which worketh in you both to will and to do of his good pleasure”—and in the afternoon from Psalm 2.11. “Serve the Lord with fear, and rejoice with trembling.” In the former discourse, the Preacher dwelt principally on the influence of the will of God; in the latter upon the causes and motives for religious fear. The Sermons very well written were delivered in a voice too cold, and with a manner not sufficiently animated.— Mr Angier is a very promising young man— It was something of a coincidence that I read the 6th. Sermon of the 3d. Volume of Saurin; upon the true object of Fear— It was like the Discourse of Mr Angier, upon the fear of God—but treated in a manner altogether different— There was no similarity either of doctrine or of argument between them— Mr Degrand came out from Boston, and dined, and spent the day with us— After the Evening Service, I walked with him over the hills— Met Judge Cranch with his Son Ch. Pearce, on the hill, near the old farm house and barn, which was his father’s, and where we used to sport together 56 years ago— There is some change even there— The house, barn, and garden of flowers, currant bushes, and Plum trees being gone— I visited also my garden and nursery with Mr Degrand.
17. III.45 Monday.

Anniversary of the Battle of Bunker’s Hill, and the burning of Charlestown; one of the first Events of which I have a personal recollection— Fifty eight years have since then elapsed— About one person in ten, then living yet exist— I was reminded of this anniversary, upon hearing with the rising Sun, a salute of 13 guns from Fort Independence; but passed the day in profound tranquility contrasting, with the deep and awful agitation of that day in 1775— I am reading and making petty annotations upon the Book of Leviticus— Strolling about my Garden and Nursery; hoeing and plucking up weeds, a never ceasing occupation— The perpetual re-appearance of weeds is an admonition to me of my own faults, and should be a warning how it is necessary to treat them—and I looked over my seedling plants, my buds and grafts as they grow—every day presenting some new aspect of observation— Planted for the first time a ripe Downton Strawberry in the Garden, and half a Kean-seedling, left by the Pirate-bird, in a cream-coloured pot— And I planted some Garden cherry Stones just ripening, and red and white Strawberries in a patch under the shade of the old St. Michael’s Pear tree— Some of my young red Oak trees, are putting forth shoots of a second growth this Season.
Elms, the seeds of which were planted the last days of May, and first week of this month, are continuing to come up— I commenced Letter 6. to Edward Livingston, and read four chapters of Otis’s Translation of the Offices.
18. IV. Tuesday.

Called from my Nursery and Garden by a visit from Mr Quincy, President of Harvard University— I asked him when it was proposed to appoint a Professor of Natural History— He said the fund bequeathed by Dr Fisher had not been received, two of the Doctor’s relatives being authorised by his Will to retain the use of the fund, for one year after his decease. I mentioned to him the desire of Dr Waterhouse to obtain this appointment, of which he said he had not been informed— He was apprehensive that Dr Waterhouse would be thought too old— I suppose him to be about 76. Mr Quincy thought Mr Nuttall, the curator of the Botanic Garden, must necessarily be the person chosen, but said Dr Harris now the Librarian had also been mentioned— Mr Nuttall is now in Europe, and Mr Quincy had been longer without hearing from him than he thought proper— He told me also that as President Jackson is about visiting Boston, the Corporation of the University had thought it necessary to invite him to visit the Colleges—that he Mr Quincy should address him in a Latin Discourse; and confer upon him the degree of Doctor of Laws— And he intimated that I should receive an invitation to be present at these ceremonies— I said that the personal Relations in which President Jackson had chosen to place himself with me were such that I could hold no intercourse of a friendly character with him— I could therefore not accept an invitation to attend upon this occasion— And independent of that, as myself an affectionate child of our alma Mater, I would not be present to witness her disgrace in conferring her highest Literary honours upon a barbarian, who could not write a sentence of Grammar, and hardly could spell his own name. Mr Quincy said he was sensible how utterly unworthy of Literary honours Jackson was; but the Corporation thought it was necessary to follow the precedent, and treat him precisely as Mr Monroe his Predecessor had been treated— As the People of the United States had seen fit to make him their President, the Corporation thought the honours which they conferred upon him were compliments due to the Station, by whomsoever it was occupied— Mr Quincy said it was thought also that the omission to shew the same respect to President Jackson, which had been shewn to Mr Monroe, would be imputed to party Spirit, which they were anxious to avoid— I was not satisfied with these reasons, but it is college ratiocination and College Sentiment— Time serving and Sycophancy are qualities of all learned and Scientific Institutions— More than 50 years since the College gave this degree of Doctor of Laws to a Frenchman by the name of Valnais, about as fit for it as Andrew Jackson— Valnais was the first French Consul at Boston, and the People were so tickled with the glory of having a Consul to reside among them, that Dr. Cooper prevailed upon the then Corporation to make him a Doctor of Laws. I had some good humoured discussion with Mr Quincy upon this occurrence, but adhered to my determination to stay at home— Mr and Mrs Foster were here this afternoon— They had been to Mr John Greenleaf’s to see Judge Cranch but he was gone out.
19. III.30. Wednesday. Boston and Quincy.

I awaked long before three O’Clock as now happens to me almost every morning. Went into Boston with Mrs Adams, Charles and his wife— Stopped at the Revd. Mr Frothingham’s— Thence to Charles’s
Office, where I met Mr Nathaniel Curtis— Walked with him and inspected the Estates which were Mr W. N. Boylston’s in Corn Court, and in Milk Street— We agreed that it will be advisable to take down the buildings now on the Land in Corn Court, and to build two Stores upon that in Milk Street— On parting from Mr Curtis, I visited the Athenaeum where the annual Exibition of Pictures is open— The Collection of works of domestic Artists, is excessively scanty and mean; but there is a Collection, by many of the Masters of the Italian and Flemish Schools, very curious and entertaining— Met Edmund Quincy there— Made remarks upon the Pictures— We dined at Mr Frothingham’s— Mrs Gorham Brooks was there; and Mr P. C. Brooks came in after dinner— We came home before Sunset; and spent the Evening at Mr Edward Miller’s. I had some conversations with his Mother, who was one of my acquaintances at Newbury-Port, from 1787 to 1790— I have not been there since that time— She was then Hannah Smith; little older than her Grand daughter is now. Mr Beale was of this Evening’s party; returned from his excursion to the interior of New-York— Mr Whitney and Mr Potter were also there— I came home excessively wearied; and I find the Society of the world becoming excessively irksome— Old age is stiffening my limbs, and fatigue is attended with lassitude, of which in youth I scarcely knew any thing but the name.
20. V:10. Thursday.

The weather is cloudy with occasional sprinklings of rain, not sufficient to lay the dust in the Streets. The drought here is already great, but with prospect of continuance months longer— The grass crop is already diminished by nearly one half from its usual produce— There is appearance that the corn, crops will largely fail— The coolness of the atmosphere and a beclouded Sun, have hitherto saved and spared much of the vegetation, but their deficiencies will very soon be distressing— I laboured morning and afternoon upon my Garden and Nursery, and am undertaking to get out a few more rocks from the Soil— My seedling Strawberries, raised in an Earthen Pot, are now bearing; and ripening— They are of the same kind with those planted for seed— I therefore now plant—the white and red of the garden—the Downton, the Kean Seedling, the Garden Railway Seedling; the Medford, and the Nursery Seedling— Seven different kinds, with the design, if life and health allow to ascertain which of them will vegetate, and which of them produce their kind— I am also now planting Cherry Stones from the Cherry trees, just now ripening in the Garden said to be the Kentish Cherry—or the red Morella. I have at least one hundred elms, growing from seeds planted since the 15th. of May— I have seven Earthen Pots, one Quart Tumbler, and one green wooden flower-box all planted with Seeds— My buds, grafts, and Seedling Trees in the Nursery and Garden, amount to several hundreds, and promise fruit,which a very few of them begin to bear.— The second shoot of the red Oaks, is already putting forth; I find only one black Oak that has it— The shoot from the Nettle-tree, which I headed down as dead, has grown fifteen inches, but a weed is the Antaeus of gardening— The beetle bug has topped one of my four beautiful Ashes, and of course arrested its growth— I linger over these things morning and afternoon, till the half days are inexcusably wasted—and I do nothing else.
21. III.50. Friday.

I rose before four O’Clock—the day was cloudy and cool, with a frequent almost imperceptible sprinkling of rain not sufficient to lay the dust in the Streets— The coolness of the weather tempts me to linger in my garden and nursery from Breakfast time till the Parish Bell for Noon recalls me to the house— The more I do the more I find to do. I made my two men John Kirk and Walterthis morning take out a rock at the lower part of my Nursery, which must have weighed at least three hundred pounds— I have found the benefit of extracting Rocks in 1830, and every place where they were is now covered with seedling trees— The fruits of my plantations, are just beginning to shew themselves, and they stimulate my fondness for
planting till it has become a ruling Passion— Still I have to learn how to devote less time to this occupation, and to better purpose— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— I received Letters from Mrs T B Adams from her Sons Isaac Hull, the Cadet at West Point, and Joseph Harrod the Midshipman at Toulon 20 April— I took them to her this afternoon— Hull has passed his examination and is admitted to the 3d Class, having risen, both in the line of study and of conduct. Jo writes like a Sailor— Mr Edward Miller came in while I was there, to invite Elizabeth to spend the Evening at his house— A Mr Wilde of Braintree came to mention a project of some persons in that town to open a new road from the foot of Penns Hill, to Capen’s lane; to shorten the distance and wind round the hill instead of ascending it— It would pass chiefly through my land, and Mr Wildes object was to ascertain whether if it should be undertaken, I should expect payment for my land which would be taken, and the cost of fencing it— I told him I thought I should, but was willing to do any thing reasonable to accommodate the petitioners for the road— He said the Commissioners were to survey the grounds next week— Mr Wild told me he was one of the Asssessors of the town of Braintree, upon whom I called in 1829. concerning an assessment which they had made on land, as belonging to me which was not mine— President Jackson is making a Northern Tour, and arrived this afternoon at Boston— I received an invitation from Lieutt. Governor Armstrong to a party at his house this Evening; and a Card from the Committee of Arrangements at Charlestown, where there is to be a procession, and Edward Everett is to deliver an Address to the President on Bunker’s Hill.
22 IV:10 Saturday.

There were copious showers in the Night, which relieved the vegetation for a few days from its perishing condition, and saved me no small number of seedling trees— I found a large breach this Morning in the Western Wall of my Nursery near the old, central Apple-tree. It had fallen in since last evening, and crushed a young Horse Chesnut and a Hickory-Walnut-tree— My two men soon put up the Wall again, and then by my direction took out two rocks weighing each from 3 to 400 pounds from the bearing ground— I had their places filled up with old manure from the Garden— I planted a row of 60 Garden Cherry Stones on the Eastern border of the patch opposite to the Nursery gate, and behind them at proper intervals a Medford—a Downton—a Nursery Seedling, and a Kean Seedling Strawberry— Marking the places where they are planted with Stakes and inscribed Stones. I found 3 new Seedling trees just up, not knowing what they are— My Elm seeds have come up more freely than any others that I ever planted— I had my patch of Railway wild Strawberry plants at the entrance of the Nursery Gate spaded up. It was over spread and smothered by clover grass— This experiment has failed, and shews that the transplantation of the plant of the wild Strawberry does not improve its fruit— I devoted the afternoon to writing. Received a Letter from John Robb acting Secretary of War; with Certificates of Pensions for David Loud and Daniel Hayward, each for 80 dollars a year from 4 March 1831 and remarks upon several other applications— There was much cannonading this afternoon, at the President’s reviewing of the Military companies in Boston. The distant Report of them gave me a double relish for the solitary tranquility of my own occupations— No period of life has ever yielded me so much quiet contentment, as that which I enjoy with my family in health about me, totally uninterrupted by visitors, and cultivating in such health as I have, my Seedling plants and trees; labouring bodily from three to four hours a day, upon horticultural experiments, all hitherto fruitless; but some few of them beginning to promise fruit— Alteri Seculo is the motto of all my plantations; but I am yet sensible and conscious that this life of pleasure is not a life of profit.
23. IV.10 Sunday.

Heard Mr Edmund Quincy Sewall, of Scituate, a graduate of 1815. in the morning from Matthew 6.6 “But thou, when thou prayest, enter into thy closet, and when thou hast shut thy door, pray to thy Father which is in secret: and thy father, which seeth in Secret shall reward thee openly.” and in the afternoon from Galatians 5.22. “But the fruit of the Spirit, is—joy.[”] I had never heard him before— His voice is not good and his articulation is indistinct; but the composition of his Sermons is very good, and his afternoon discourse was occasionally pathetic— Religious sentimentalism, is the most common characteristic of the writings of the young Unitarian Sons of Harvard University— I read the seventh Sermon of the 3d. volume of Saurin; upon the difficulties of the Christian Religion— An argumentative disquisition—very elaborate and very ingenious. He contrasts Christianity, with Paganism, Mahometanism, Popery and Infidelity—in all of which he insists there are greater difficulities than in Christianity— His greatest Labour is to prove the propriety of believing the Trinity and rejecting Transubstantiation— I read also the performances at the Installation of Mr Andrew Bigelow, as Minister of the Unitarian Church at Taunton; and a Sermon of his own preached at Derry, New Hampshire, upon Christian Liberty— I spent the Evening at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s, where I met two young Ladies of Mrs Baxter’s family.
24. IV. Monday— St. John’s day.

Mr Eli Cook came this morning and produced an order upon me to pay him the proceeds of the Land Scrip, which I sold for the Holmes family, at Washington— The order was signed only by Josiah Holmes, of Kingston— I paid him 112 dollars and 50 cents, and took his receipt in behalf of Josiah, Mary and Lois Holmes— The remainder of the morning from breakfast till near One O’Clock, I was in my Garden and Nursery, where the late rain has produced fresh growth of nothing but weeds.— I found two new Enemies to my trees—the first of this Season—the Rosebug and Slug worm— Gathered the last remnants from the two Garden (Kentish) Cherry-trees— The fruit is not yet quite ripe, but the birds have carried off at least half of it, and in three days more would have totally strippd the trees. This is an excellent cherry, and I wish if possible to raise trees from its stones— I gathered a large number of them from the trees; but of these at least four out of five float in water, and their kernels wither and shrivel in the shell without ripening.— This happens to almost all budded and grafted cherries— I walked about Sunset to Mr Quincy’s gate— Mr Beale spent the Evening here; just returned from his excursion to the Western part of the State of New-York; with which he has been much gratified. This day is one of those anniversaries which bring to my mind placid recollections. It is that of my arrival at Ghent— There is in the remembrance of the large half year which I passed in that City, a charm, belonging to no other period of my life— The Scenery through which I had passed from the painful day where I left my wife and Son Charles at St. Petersburg—the deep anxiety and almost despondency with which I looked forward to the prospect of failure in the object of the Mission; the kindness and courtesy which I experienced from the Inhabitants of Ghent during the whole term of our residence there—the comfort and tranquility, and friendly hospitality which marked the mode of existence of the People, the trying struggles and collisions, with the British Commissioners, and with my own colleagues which I underwent; the success beyond my most sanguine expectations which closed the Negotiation and the subsequent signal discomfiture of a dark conspiracy there concerted against my character and good name have endeared that period of my life to my memory beyond any other— I arrived at Ghent, in company with Jonathan Russell, who then
wore the mask of friendship— He is gone to his account, and was sufficiently punished in this world for his perfidy— And Bayard is gone; and in the most recent reports from England, I see announced the death of Lord Gambier, the first of the British Plenipotentiaries— Nineteen years have passed away since we met— I have since then endured great vicissitudes, deep distresses, and insidious prosperities—a merciful and protecting Providence has led me through them all. The Transactions at Ghent were the most fortunate occurrences of my life.
25. IV:20. Tuesday

A cold Northeasterly storm with rain almost without interruption the whole day. I was confined to my chamber with two or three intermissions, in which a sprinkling compelled me to return to the house— I despatched a number of public documents of which I receive several by every day’s Mail— The President, must hasten back to Washington, or he will be glorified into his grave— They fagged him by their reception on Friday, and their presentations and Addresses on Saturday that he failed going to Brattle-Street Church with Governor Lincoln on Sunday Morning; but made out to go with Lieutt. Governor Armstrong to the old South Church in the afternoon— Monday Morning there were to be two exhibitions; one putting the Constitution Frigate in the new Dry Dock at the Navy-yard, Charlestown—the other was an Address delivered to him on Bunker’s Hill by Edward Everett; and in the afternoon, he was to receive his scientific honours at Harvard University— He was sick in bed the whole day under the care of Dr Warren— This day, the weather alone would keep him in his lodgings at the Tremont-house; but he is convalescent— The Constitution went into dry dock without him— The Bunker’s Hill and Harvard University decorations are postponed.
26. IV.45. Wednesday.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— The morning and evening were clear, with sprinkling showers in the middle of the day— The President went this day to Cambridge, and received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws— Mr Quincy delivered an Address to him in English, and a member of the Senior Class an Oration in Latin— From thence the President returned to Charlestown, where Mr Edward Everett delivered the Address to him on Bunker’s Hill, after which he proceeded to Salem. My Son John’s daughter Louisa was this day taken unwell while she was reading to me. She was confined the rest of the day to the chamber. I measured again the ghost from the bud twig in the Apple stock which Price Greenleaf inserted in August 1831. and which first put forth about the first of August last year— The stem of this Season has grown 28 inches since the first of May— From this and other observations, I mark half an inch a day as the proper growth of a thrifty shoot of a fruit tree— But of my seedlings of Apples and cherries of the present year, the best are not more than 3 inches high— The Apple which came up on the 21st. of April, and of which about a fortnight since the Stem was broken off to the first leaf and with it one lobe of the Seed leaves, yet survive, and has put forth 3 new leaves— After Sunset I walked to the sixth Milestone and back.
27. IV. Thursday.

The Sun rose and sat perfectly clear; but there were heavy Showers before noon. I was working in my Nursery, till Doctor Waterhouse came and dined with us— The Doctor is now near fourscore years of age—and his Constitution seems to be breaking up. He told me that he had never felt the effects of old age so much, as within the last six Months, and that this would probably be the last visit he should pay me— He found it troublesome to go so far from home, and must soon shut himself up and keep house— He was however present yesterday at the ceremony of conferring the Degree of Doctor of Laws upon President
Jackson, and was much captivated by the ease and gracefulness of his manners. He shook hands with him twice, and told him he had heard of him many years ago; and was very glad to take him by the hand now— But he says Jackson is so excessively debilitated that he should not be surprized if he should never reach Washington again— I believe much of his debility is politic—part his own policy to suit his returns of civility to his own convenience, and pleasure, and part the policy of his physicians, pour se faire valoir— He is one of our tribes of great men, who turn disease to commodity, like John Randolph, who for forty years, were always dying— Jackson ever since he became a mark of public attention has been doing the same thing— He is so ravenous of notoriety, that he craves the sympathy for sickness as a portion of his glory— He is now alternately, giving out his chronic diarrhea, and making Warren bleed him for a Pleurisy, and posting to Cambridge for a doctorate of Laws, mounting the monument of Bunkers Hill to hear a fulsome address and receive two Cannon-Balls from Edward Everett, and riding Post to Lynn, Marblehead and Salem, receiving Collations, deputations and addresses at them all, in one and the same day—four fifths of his Sickness is trickery, and the other fifth mere fatigue— He will drag himself along in this way—disconcerting all the costly arrangements for his reception—disappointing three fourths of the People, male and female, who are agonizing to see him, and boast all their lives of having shaken hands with him, and finally crawl back to Washington, perhaps shut himself up one or two days, and then come forth in the Globe; never in better health and Spirits and determined to live these twenty years— Dr Waterhouse discussed the propriety of the University’s conferring upon him a Doctorate of Laws— I said a Doctorate for which an Apology was necessary, was a cheap honour, and that I thought it a Sycophantic compliment— The Doctor said it was thus truly characterised— He consulted me upon a point of some delicacy— He has received confidential Statements which he believes true, that one of the teachers of the University has a secret and infamous vice— Is it his duty to expose the man? I told him I thought the President of the University ought to be apprized of the facts— Whether he should tell him or not, depended upon the question, whether his relations with the inculpated party were or were not such that his information might be imputed to personal enmity— If not, he should make the communication confidentially— If they were, he might advise the person who made the Statements to him, to make them to President Quincy— This was my advice— The Doctor left us at four O’Clock to return home— Our Ladies went to Weymouth and took tea with Mrs Tufts— I walked to Mr Quincy’s gate, and observed his Hedge of Scotch Hawthorn in full blossom— I am adopting the practice of ticketing my seedling plants upon small Stones. Charles went to Boston and returned to dine.
28. IV. Friday.

Morning devoted to writing, and to the Garden and Nursery. Resuming the arrears of the Index to my Diary, in bringing up which I was arrested by illness last January— I went in my Chaise with John Kirk to Boston, and dined with the Lieutt. Governor Samuel T. Armstrong— The Company were Commodore and Mrs Elliot. He is now stationed at the Navy-Yard, in Charlestown—Mrs Abbott Lawrence—Her Husband was at Lowell—Mr and Mrs Cobb—Mr and Mrs Samuel Welles— They are here on a visit to their friends— They have resided many years in Paris— Miss Walker, whom the Lieutt. Governor introduced as his Sister— Mr. Mann formerly of Dedham; lately removed to Boston and a Mr Welsh, to me a Stranger.
Commodore Elliot had been yesterday at the Presidents procession at Lowell; which as usual he was just able to get through, and then retired to bed— This day he departs from Lowell, and proceeds to Concord New-Hampshire— The dinner at Mr Armstrong’s was as pleasant as a company so mixed could make it— The Company broke up about 7. and I came immediately home—
29. IV. Saturday.

My Son Charles’s wife left us this morning to make a visit of ten days to her father at Medford; with her child, Louisa. Charles himself went to Boston, and returned here to dine— Kirk brought black and white Heart cherries, and a half-bushel of Ohio Walnuts from Boston— They were advertised in a Newspaper as very large, but only a small portion of them answer to that description, and they all float in water. Elijah Spear was here with a bill of wharfage, for the books which arrived here last Winter from Washington, and a small bill for putting up a fence for me— Judge Cranch and Mrs Cranch were here, with Mr John Greenleaf’s daughter Mary and William Elliot— I was great part of the morning in my Garden and Nursery; and towards Sunset walked with the child Louisa to the Stone Meeting-House and back— The Walnuts planted the last Autumn, are now just beginning to come up above the surface. I have two in the Nursery which appear within the last two days—
30— IV:30. Sunday.

Mr Deane of Scituate preached in the forenoon from John 6.68. Then Simon Peter answered him, Lord, to whom shall we go?— Thou hast the words of eternal Life— Upon the dignity of the Christian Religion—and after dinner, from John 8.12 [“]Then spake Jesus again unto them, saying I am the light of the world” both argumentative discourses— Mr Deane dined with us— He is one of the most intelligent Clergymen of this neighbourhood, but our Parish think his prayers are too long— I read a Sermon of Saurin, the 8th. of the 3d. Volume upon Proverbs 23.23—the purchase of Truth. In general the Discourses of this Volume are superior to those of the preceding Volumes. I mentioned to Mr Deane that in the Summer of 1806 I had heard, Mr Samuel Sewall read at the Episcopal Church in Cambridge, a Sermon of Sherlock upon the same text, which he had taken this Morning— That this Sermon had made so deep an impression upon my mind that it had remained upon my Memory to this time, but that he had treated the subject in a different manner. He said he had never read that Sermon of Sherlock— In the Evening I went with Mrs Adams, Charles, and Louisa, and paid a visit to Coll. and Mrs Josiah Quincy junr. who came out from Boston to their Country Seat yesterday— They spend a very small portion of the Summer here— The fashion of Summer Residence in the Country, is very much abating, as that of Summer travelling, and frequenting watering-places has greatly increased. There are fewer Summer residents in Quincy than there were 25 years ago, although the population of the town in that time has nearly doubled.

Day.— I rise between four and five O’Clock; in time to see the Sun rise, from my South-eastern window. It rises here at 4.28 at the time of the Solstice and now at 4:30— I take half an hour or more, for ablutions— Then read and make a few annotations upon four chapters of Thomson’s Translation of the Septuagint Bible— We breakfast between 7. and 8. after which I spend from three to four hours in my Garden and Nursery; digging up weeds, inspecting my seedling plants, and planting seeds, nuts and Stones— Read or write from Noon till two— Dine. Idle away the afternoon, with occasional reading, writing, and visiting my Garden till Sunset. Evening with my family.
